article: How to Get Rid of Cicadas (And, When Do They Come Out?)
intro: Some cicadas emerge from the ground every year, while others operate on a 13- or 17-year cycle. There’s no way to totally stop cicadas, but they don’t bite or sting, and they do minimal damage to most plants, so a little diligence and damage control is all that’s needed. That’s why we're here to give you the best tips on preventing cicada damage and getting rid of cicadas, and also give you an overview on these occasional critters, so that you know what to expect during the next cicada season.

steps.title: Wait until after a cicada year to plant new trees.
steps.subtitle: Young trees are more at-risk for cicada damage, so it’s generally recommended that, if you plan to plant anything new, you do it after a cicada season, or 2 years beforehand.
sub-points: Trees that are especially at-risk include fruit trees, oak, maple, chestnut, dogwood, elm, and ash.

points.name: When and where will cicadas emerge in 2024?

steps.title: The cicadas will mostly originate in Illinois.
steps.subtitle: Both broods are based in Illinois. Brood XIII emerges in northern Illinois, while XIX is a southern Illinois brood. That said, cicadas will be present in many neighboring states, including Wisconsin, Iowa, Missouri, and Arkansas, and may find their way as far west as Oklahoma, or even east to the coast.
sub-points: Though the broods will emerge simultaneously, their range largely won’t overlap, so there most likely won’t be any more cicadas in any one place than during a usual emergence.

steps.title: Cicadas live most of their lives in underground burrows.
steps.subtitle: When cicada eggs hatch, they produce “nymphs” that fall to the ground and burrow into the earth, where they spend the next 1-17 years (depending on species) feeding off nutrients in tree roots. Then, they emerge, climb a tree, molt their exoskeleton, and become mature cicadas ready to do the whole thing over again.
sub-points: Cicadas don’t typically kill off the tree they feed on, unless that tree is particularly young or already weak.
